utterances: There is a vast reluctance to create uniformity in terms of either quality or curriculum.
That's an accurate quote, and thank you for reading it.
It is the only time in the book that I talk about the process that we used in order to make a decision to raise the threat level.

It's the only discussion where I mention the parties, and there are other people, obviously, involved in that discussion because the Homeland Security Council comprised about two-thirds of the president's Cabinet.
I think he is to - I think he is right.
Revolution may come.
It may not be a revolution he likes because remember that when he was prime minister, he also removed judges.
So this is an old tradition in Pakistan.
But it really is a revolution.

For two years now - this started in March of 2007 - for two years now, people in Pakistan, led by the lawyers, but ordinary people have been running a movement that is peaceful, that is democratic, that is asking for the restoration of justice and institutions.
For two years, under very, very difficult circumstances, they've been beaten up, they have been put into jails.
People have disappeared and yet they have been persistent for two years.
I think the revolution has happened.
I would argue that had this happened anywhere else, we would have been giving it a color, you know, it would be the Orange Revolution, or the Green Revolution or the Velvet Revolution.
But it's a movement that started against General Musharraf.
It was highly influential in the removal of General Musharraf.
Now it is highly influential in the reinstatement of the chief justice and it is not going to be Nawaz Sharif's movement or Asif Zardari's movement.
In some ways, it is amongst the very, very, very few good things happening in Pakistan.
The revolution in search of the title.
Professor Najam thanks very much.
thank you.
Adil Najam is Professor of International Relations at Boston University.
He also writes the blog All Things Pakistan at pakistania.com.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Michele Norris.
How big is too big to fail?
So far, Washington's answer has varied.
AIG is and continues to be too big to fail.
Bear Stearns and even Lehman Brothers were not.
And now the government appears to be taking over Citigroup on the assumption that it is too big to fail.
There are some dissenters.
Alabama Republican Senator Richard Shelby told George Stephanopoulos on ABC yesterday some big banks ought to be allowed to fail.
Close them down, get them out of business.
If they're dead, they ought to be buried.
We bury the small banks.
We've got to bury some big ones and send a strong message to the market.
And I believe that people will start investing in banks.
People aren't buying...
Are you talking Citigroup?
Well, whatever.
Citi's always been a problem child.
: Well, joining us now our two economists: Professor Kenneth Rogoff of Harvard and Adam Posen of the Peterson Institute for International Economics.
Welcome both of you.
Thank you, Robert.
Thank you.
: And first, Adam Posen, is a failure by Citi something that is so much bigger, say, than the failure of Lehman Brothers that the government must do something to contain it?
Well, they're going to let it actually fail, Robert.
I mean, that's the point of having the government step in and take over, and we have laws on the books for how you unwind a bank.
The thing is you do do euthanasia, and that's what we're talking about here.
I mean, Mr. Shelby, Senator Shelby is exaggerating to say we just let them collapse.
We didn't even just let IndyMac collapse.
But you definitely want to get them on a path where they don't get walking around zombie-like, passing out bad loans and burning through taxpayer money.

: Kenneth Rogoff, you were on John McCain's team of advisors last year, and yesterday he said this about the Obama administration: I don't think they've made the hard decision, and that is to let these banks fail.
Has he got it right?
I think he has had absolutely right.
I think that the banks are going to need to go through some kind of receivership.
The question is how fast.
They're not viable.
The amount of taxpayer money that's going to have to go in is in the trillions to fix them, and I don't think that's going to happen.
Frankly, if it did, we could solve the problem that way.
I completely agree with what Adam said, but the sticking point is, of course, banks make loans, but these banks took out loans, also.
And what happens to them?
We all agree we should pay off the depositors.
But the so-called bond holders - which could include insurance companies, pension funds - that basically lent money to Citibank, what you had do with them?
I think that these people who have lent money to Citibank ought to kick in some of the money also.
That's what a real bankruptcy is.
: Well, here comes another kind of too big-too-fail question that's coming at us from Detroit.
General Motors, at its present size, is generally considered too big to succeed.
Is it also too big to fail?
Must the US have a big auto company like that?
Kenneth Rogoff, what do you say?
Well, I don't think the U.S.
is going to have big auto production in 15 or 20 years any more than we're making flat panel TV screens today.
We may be very involved in the design phase.
We may make some of the high-end parts for autos.
But unless we have trade restrictions that prevent autos from coming in from Asia, I just don't see it.
So it's a very different from the banking system.
: Adam Posen, what about General Motors?
They, too, not only have autoworkers whom they employ, but also suppliers, dealers, people in the service and parts departments of those dealerships.
This is a big enterprise.
Save it?
Let it die?
Which one?
If it wasn't the middle of the recession, I would have said let it die.
The issue is when we're in the midst of this horrible downturn, do you want that sudden sharp a blow of particular regions of industries, particular sets of businesses being wiped out at a glance?
And I don't think you can afford that under the current circumstances.
I think if GM had gone under through capital market pressures in normal times - which frankly, it probably should have - then there would have been no reason to keep it alive.
But right now, if we had a better welfare state in this country, maybe I'd let it go.
But under the current circumstance, I can't see doing it.
: By the way...
If I might...
: Yes, Kenneth Rogoff.
If I might comment, I mean, but people in the tax sector and biotech will say, well, fine.
Why are you subsidizing this dying industry?
We're hurting from this recession, too.
Why not subsidized us?
Do we have other sectors that really represent our future?
Why are we bailing out the auto industry and letting, you know, them suffer so much?
They're having a lot of problem, also.
I did baseball.
I did soccer.
I did some other sports.
(Laughter) I'm not good at them, but I tried them.
And all of a sudden, racing came up.
It's like, ooh (ph), I'm good at this.
This is good.
He isn't just good.
Last year, at 14, Lothian was the best racer in his class, beating kids and adults.
Cindy Lothian is Blake's mom.
With Blake, it wasn't that he just wanted to do it.
It was that when he did it, from the time he was 5, he was really, really good at it where people noticed.
Blake Lothian is a rarity in his wealthy Boston suburb where good grades, sports and other extracurricular activities are the ticket to college.
For the Lothians, go-kart racing is Blake's ticket to NASCAR.
They've got it all planned out.
College, Cindy Lothian says, can wait.
You don't have to start college when you're 18.
There's no law that says you have to, you know?
And this is the way it works.
Most NASCAR drivers began as kids racing karts.
(SOUNDBITE OF ENGINE REVVING)
After blowing away the field last year, Lothian is racing in a new category with a new kart that goes way faster - about 65, 70 miles an hour.
And the competition is rough.
The drivers, mostly men well into adulthood, have acquired the nickname hooligans because they're not always so nice on the track.
(SOUNDBITE OF GO-KART RACE)
Lothian does a lot of his races here at a go-kart track outside the New Hampshire Motor Speedway in Loudon, a mecca for regional NASCAR fans.
Everyone here knows Lothian and what he did last year, and the entire field wants to make sure he doesn't do it again.
Well, today I'm expecting just a solid top 10 performance because, you know, first time in this engine, first time just with all this new equipment, just not sure what to expect.
The competition is a series of three races, the first two determining where you start in the final.
Lothian does fine in the first race, but in the second...
Someone spun out going backwards, basically just grazed me.
He was left stranded on the grass in the middle of the course.
It was an ignominious beginning and meant he'd start at the back of the pack for the final race.
But Lothian saw that as a challenge.
You want to go in there thinking, like, this is just another chance to pass more karts - just make it look cooler.
And in the final, in the last lap at the last turn in the last race of the day, it looked like Lothian had pulled ahead.
And when the results came out, he was in third place.
Way to go.
I got third?
Yes.
Yes.
I just started from, like, second to last, and I made up to third.
Oh, man.
Blake's parents are ecstatic.

It's confirmation that their family's dream may be on track that within the next two years, Blake will be out of the go-kart and on to the main stage - that oval NASCAR track he can see just over the hill from the third-place podium.
For NPR News, I'm Aaron Schachter.
